28.12.text: Hello. Two teams have already received, with rather mixed feelings,

32.48.text: the news that they're through to the semifinal stage of our

38.76.text: Those teams are from Manchester University and Magdalene College, Oxford.

42.88.text: Now first, the team representing the ancient University of Aberdeen,

48.72.text: Their first team member threw away a promising early career as a postman,

52.96.text: and is now a television executive.

55.04.text: A former controller of BBC Four,

56.76.text: he is currently the Director Of Factual Programmes at ITV.

60.80.text: With him is a familiar face from the other side of the camera as the

64.20.text: presenter of the BBC's religious and ethical debate programme,

67.04.text: The Big Questions, as well as ITV's Long Lost Family

70.68.text: and the Radio 5 Live Breakfast programme.

73.92.text: Their captain specialises in marine science.

76.48.text: He's worked for the British Antarctic Survey,

79.08.text: advised the US Navy on how military sonars affect the whale population

84.16.text: and he's the author and editor of several books on the Hebrides.

87.92.text: Joining them is a politician whose career so far has included

91.36.text: tenures as Scottish Labour's Shadow Minister for Youth Employment

95.20.text: and Shadow Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning.

102.12.text: My name is Richard Klein, I graduated from Aberdeen in 1983,

105.16.text: and I now work in television.

108.68.text: My name is Nicky Campbell, I graduated in 1982,

112.72.text: these days I ask questions, but very rarely answer any.

118.84.text: My name is Ian Boyd, I graduated in 1979 in zoology.

122.48.text: I'm now a professor at the University of St Andrews

127.52.text: to the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.

131.80.text: I'm Kezia Dugdale, I graduated from Aberdeen University in law in 2003.

136.60.text: I'm a member of the Scottish Parliament

138.48.text: and the leader of the Scottish Labour Party.

145.48.text: The University of Sheffield is a much more recent institution at a mere 110 years old,

151.16.text: and the team playing on its behalf tonight includes

154.12.text: a sports journalist who lives in Madrid and writes about football -

157.72.text: a career that on the face of it appears to have no downside.

161.00.text: His reports appear in the Guardian and he also contributes to the

164.12.text: US cable channel ESPN and World Soccer.

168.24.text: Next, a former literary editor of the New Statesman and the Observer.

171.48.text: For the past 20 years, she's collaborated with her husband,

174.40.text: Sean French, under the joint pseudonym Nicci French

178.00.text: on a series of bestselling literary thrillers.

181.32.text: Their captain is an award-winning academic author, broadcaster

185.28.text: and the go-to man on everything to do with insects.

188.04.text: He's recently been a presenter on the BBC's Hive Alive

193.52.text: 2015 saw the publication of his book on bacteria, The Life Of Poo.

198.64.text: Their fourth member's career in architecture spans both public

202.00.text: and private practice as well as the Planning Inspectorate, the Government

205.36.text: agency responsible for the final outcome of town planning decisions.

209.24.text: She has a particular interest in planning for sensitive rural areas,

212.68.text: and she was awarded a professorship by Birmingham City University

216.28.text: for her contribution to the profession.

220.40.text: Hello, I'm Sid Lowe, I first went to Sheffield around about 21 years ago.

223.60.text: It's taken almost as long for me to leave.

225.36.text: I'm now a sports journalist and historian in Madrid.

231.08.text: and I was at Sheffield doing an MA more than 30 years ago.

235.08.text: Now I'm a novelist and a journalist.

238.84.text: Hello, I'm Adam Hart, I graduated in 2001 with a PhD in zoology,

242.04.text: and I'm now a broadcaster, author

247.68.text: Hello, I'm Ruth Reed, I graduated as an architect from Sheffield in 1982.

252.04.text: I became the first woman president

254.12.text: of the Royal Institute of British Architects.

262.04.text: OK, the rules are constant as the Northern Star,

265.16.text: so ten points for starters, 15 for bonuses,

267.52.text: there's a five-point fine if you interrupt a starter question incorrectly.

271.72.text: Right, fingers on the buzzers, here's your first starter for ten:

277.16.text: This New Noise, is a history of which institution?

281.16.text: Founded in the 1920s, one of its founding figures said it should be,

292.64.text: You get the first set of bonuses, then, Aberdeen.

298.56.text: which personification is said to have come into widespread use after

302.12.text: barrels of meat were stamped with the character's two initials

305.48.text: during the War of 1812 to indicate that they were government property?

318.36.text:
- We don't know. 
- It's Uncle Sam.

320.16.text: Which personification was popularised by a character of the same

323.60.text: name in John Arbuthnot's 1712 satire, The Law Is A Bottomless Pit?

337.24.text: And finally, in the 1960s, Bridget Bardot became the first living

340.68.text: person to act as the model for official busts of which figure?

344.52.text: The personification of the French Republic.

352.04.text: No, its Marianne! Ten points for this:

356.80.text: "when trying to design something completely foolproof

360.16.text: "is to underestimate the ingenuity of complete fools."

364.04.text: Who wrote these words in the 1992 novel, Mostly Harmless?

377.32.text: Sheffield, your bonuses are on the characters in the novels of Jane Austen.

381.64.text: I want you to give me the surname, please, of each of the following.

384.52.text: Firstly: What is the surname of Captain Frederick,

388.32.text: who in Persuasion was formally betrothed to Anne Elliott?

395.28.text:
- I think it's Weston, but I don't know. 
- Frederick Weston?

397.80.text:
- I don't know. 
- No, I don't know. Go with Weston.

403.64.text:
- No, it's Wentworth. 
- Argh! 
- Bad luck!

408.36.text: What was the surname of Mr John, who rescues Marianne Dashwood

412.60.text: from a rainstorm in Sense and Sensibility?

426.32.text: who in Pride And Prejudice has an income in excess of 10,000 a year?

437.44.text:
- Is that Darcy? 
- Is it Darcy? 
- Could be Darcy. 
- But is...

445.96.text: Who, in January 2015, became the Church of England's first

449.08.text: female bishop on her consecration in York Minster as Bishop of Stockport?

457.40.text:
- Elizabeth Lane? 
- Correct, yes. Or Libby Lane, for short.

463.48.text: Your bonuses, Sheffield, this time are on scientists and inventors.

467.32.text: Name each person from the description, please.

469.92.text: Firstly, born in the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1856,

473.48.text: he moved to New York in 1884.

476.40.text: He patented the rotating magnetic field

479.12.text: and developed the three-phase system of electric power transmission?

487.96.text: He was based in Britain, wasn't he?

492.48.text:
- It's not Tesla, is it? 
- Could be.

495.08.text:
- Tesla? 
- It is Nikola Tesla, yes.

500.40.text: he accidentally discovered the process of vulcanisation.

504.64.text: Although he was financially unsuccessful during his lifetime,

508.04.text: A tyre company founded in 1898 and named after him

512.28.text: now has a total equity of around 3.6 billion.

517.44.text: No, he was Scottish, wasn't he? It was Charles Goodyear.

521.16.text: A noted exponent of the scientific method, born in Cornwall in 1778,

526.00.text: he discovered potassium and sodium and invented the miner's safety lamp.

532.88.text: We're going to take our first picture round.

534.80.text: For your picture starter you're going to see a quotation from a play by

538.32.text: Shakespeare, from which the name of a month of the year has been removed.

542.04.text: For ten points, please give me the missing month.

552.20.text: Anyone like to buzz from Sheffield?

555.28.text:
- December. 
- December. Let's see the whole thing?

561.04.text: It's Rosalind to Orlando in As You Like It.

563.64.text: For your picture bonuses, three more quotations from Shakespeare's

566.80.text: plays from which the name of a month of the year has been removed.

570.08.text: Again, in each case, five points if you can tell me the missing month.

583.04.text:
- It's got to be winter. 
- November?

587.48.text: What shall we go for? What do you think? November face?

593.16.text: It's Pedro to Benedick in Much Ado.

600.52.text: Aye, well, cuckoo's normally May, aren't they?

604.04.text:
- May. 
- No, it's June, I'm afraid.

606.84.text: That's from Henry IV, about his predecessor,

610.24.text: to Prince Hal in Henry IV Part 1.

622.32.text:
- Yeah, showers. 
- It's got to be. 
- Yeah. 
- OK.

630.84.text: We're going to take another starter question now.

635.24.text: what generic two-word term denotes the method of running application

638.56.text: software and storing data centrally, while providing users with access

642.72.text: to both applications and data through the internet?

650.44.text: Yes, I'll accept. Cloud computing, yes.

658.04.text: Your bonuses are on the US filmmaker Sofia Coppola.

670.04.text: It's set largely in a Tokyo hotel.

675.88.text: Give the rhyming title of the 2013 film by Coppola,

679.08.text: based on actual events, in which a group of California teenagers

689.68.text:
- Don't know. 
- It's The Bling Ring.

693.84.text: Kirsten Dunst played the title character in which 2006 film directed

696.92.text: by Coppola, the winner of the Academy Award for Best Costume Design?

700.40.text: It's an adaptation of Antonia Fraser's biography

703.04.text: of a royal figure born in 1755.

719.72.text: It WAS Marie Antoinette, bad luck.

723.24.text: Which feast day is celebrated in the Western Christian Church on December the 28th?

727.64.text: It marks the narrative in Matthew's gospel,

729.84.text: according to which, King Herod ordered the death of all children

732.64.text: of two years and under, in the neighbourhood of Bethlehem?

743.64.text: Anyone want to buzz from Sheffield?

750.36.text: I'll accept that, it is the Holy Innocents Day,

753.20.text: or the Massacre or The Feast of the Holy Innocents.

755.48.text: So you get a set of bonuses, this time, on 20th-century art, Sheffield.

759.56.text: Which movement was founded in Amsterdam in 1917?

764.80.text: advocated pure abstraction, reduced to essential forms and colours.

785.36.text: And secondly, Henri Matisse was the acknowledged leader of which movement?

789.88.text: Prominent in France and first exhibiting formally in 1905,

793.64.text: its artists used pure, bright colours applied vigorously to the canvas.

804.24.text: Which movement's name means hobby horse in French

807.20.text: and is thought to have been adopted in Zurich around 1916?

818.36.text:
- What do you think? 
- French for horse is cheval, right?

830.08.text: Ten points for this starter question:

831.84.text: Its name derived from the Greek for glue-producing, which fibrous,

835.00.text: structural protein is noted for its extremely high tensile strength

839.40.text: and is the major component of connective tissues...

860.48.text: can occupy a particular quantum state at any given time.

867.60.text: What is the umbrella name for those bosons that mediate

876.28.text: I looked at this the other night as well.

882.04.text:
- I don't know. 
- They're gauge bosons.

884.44.text: And finally, there are four types of gauge boson - photons,

887.52.text: gravitons, intermediate vector bosons, and which others?

894.64.text: We're now going to take a music round.

896.52.text: For your music starter you'll hear a song from a film soundtrack,

899.60.text: for ten points, I'd just like you to identify the person singing, please.

913.28.text: High Hopes, from A Hole In The Head.

915.00.text: And so, December 2015 marks Sinatra's centenary.

920.92.text: three more of his musical performances from films, and this

923.92.text: time, in each case, I'd like the name of the film that each comes from.

936.08.text: Lady is a Tramp, what's the film?

950.76.text:
- Originally. 
- # That's why the Lady is a Tramp. #

957.44.text:
- I don't think we know that one. 
- Don't know.

959.80.text: That's from Pal Joey, it was The Lady Is A Tramp.

970.20.text:
- Blimey. 
- # Is taking a chance on me

976.68.text: # Taking a chance, I'll be respectable and nice... #

980.32.text: Can we just listen to some more of these? They're great.

987.56.text: That's from Guys And Dolls. And finally:

991.48.text:
- # Who wants to be a millionaire? 
- I don't...

1002.16.text: What is the common name of Taxus baccata, a conifer often found...?

1007.92.text:
- A yew. 
- Yew is correct, yes.

1012.36.text: Sheffield, these bonuses are on the ballet The Nutcracker.

1017.52.text: The scenario of Tchaikovsky's 1892 ballet The Nutcracker is

1020.88.text: based on Alexander Dumas pere's adaptation of the story

1024.44.text: The Nutcracker And The Mouse King, by which German author?

1029.80.text: Is it...? Is Hans Christian Andersen German...?

1034.68.text:
- No, he's Danish, wasn't he? 
- Danish.

1038.44.text:
- Grimm was German. 
- Go for Grimm.

1044.44.text: Described by him as something between a small piano

1047.36.text: and a glockenspiel, what instrument did Tchaikovsky

1050.64.text: use for the score accompanying the Sugarplum Fairy's solo variation?

1054.68.text:
- That's the, kind of, doo-doo-doo-doo-doo. 
- What?

1059.96.text:
- Harpsichord? 
- No, it was a celeste.

1062.44.text: In 1992, which British choreographer created a new

1065.48.text: version of the ballet to celebrate its centenary?

1068.36.text: It opens in a bleak orphanage.

1075.28.text: Celebrating his 80th anniversary in 2016, which comic strip character

1079.92.text: is a mischievous nine-year-old boy from the fictional town...?

1083.88.text:
- Dennis the Menace. 
- No, you lose five points.

1087.12.text: Fictional town of Auchenshoogle, and appears in Scotland's...?

1091.44.text:
- Oor Wullie. 
- Oor Wullie is right, yes!

1098.16.text: You'll be pleased to hear, Aberdeen, your bonuses are on fish.

1102.44.text: Give the name of each of the following,

1104.20.text: all three answers include the word fish - for example, goldfish.

1108.60.text: Amphiprion ocellaris, a small fish noted for its association with

1120.24.text: Secondly, Clarias batrachus, native to south-east Asia, its two-word

1124.80.text: common name refers to its ability to move on land using its pectoral fins.

1136.28.text: a food and game fish that can grow up to four metres in length.

1140.04.text: Its common name refers to its distinctive bill.

1148.52.text: What is the six-letter common name of Cimex lectularius?

1152.36.text: With atrophied, non-functioning wings and a distinctive oily odour,

1156.24.text: it is a species of nocturnal parasite whose numbers are said to have

1170.72.text: Aberdeen, your bonuses are on former Bank of England notes.

1175.00.text: In each case, I need the name of the person described

1177.60.text: and the domination of the banknote on which they appeared. Firstly:

1181.40.text: A scientist and Warden of the Mint, born in 1642.

1184.88.text: The banknote on which he appeared was issued in 1978

1199.12.text: No, it was Sir Isaac Newton on a £1 note.

1202.16.text: Secondly: An inventor and engineer born in 1781.

1205.56.text: The banknote was first issued in 1990 and withdrawn in 2003.

1219.08.text:
- When was James Watt? 
- 1781... Could be.

1223.92.text: No, it was George Stephenson on the £5 note.

1228.72.text: The banknote was first issued in 1981 and withdrawn in 1996.

1241.00.text: No, it was the £50 note. Bad luck, I can't accept that.

1244.12.text: We're going to take our second picture round now.

1246.56.text: For your picture starter you're going to see a photograph of a bird.

1249.88.text: For ten points I'd like you to give me

1251.88.text: the common, two-word name of the species.

1257.72.text:
- Arctic tern. 
- It is an Arctic tern, yes.

1262.96.text: Its seasonal migration from pole to pole is one of the longest known.

1267.84.text: three more species that make notably long seasonal migrations.

1271.44.text: Five points for each species you can identify.

1273.88.text: Again, I'm simply looking for the common name.

1280.92.text: It is a wildebeest, or a gnu.

1285.84.text: a 1,200 mile journey across the Serengeti,

1287.96.text: away from the dry season, apparently, each year.

1296.68.text: Yes, they migrate thousands of miles between breeding and feeding areas.

1304.28.text: It is indeed, they fly up to 2,000 miles south for the winter.

1310.08.text: Ten points for this starter question:

1312.04.text: On the final day of the first Test in Antigua in April 2015,

1317.08.text: which bowler broke Sir Ian Botham's England wicket record

1321.04.text: with his 384th dismissal in his 100th match?

1327.88.text:
- James Anderson. 
- It was indeed, yes.

1334.52.text: are on Kenneth Grahame's The Wind In The Willows.

1336.84.text: In each case, name the character from its scientific name.

1340.00.text: Firstly, which character's name has the binomial Meles meles?

1346.24.text: Secondly, which character's name may be rendered binomially as Bufo bufo?

1353.68.text: And finally, Talpa europaea is the binomial of which character?

1365.64.text: A narration by John Grierson, a soundtrack by Benjamin Britten

1368.96.text: and poetry by WH Auden feature in which 1936 documentary film,

1374.08.text: depicting the journey of a steam locomotive travelling to

1381.00.text:
- The Night Mail. 
- The Night Mail is right, yes.

1386.00.text: Your bonuses, Sheffield, are on the artist and filmmaker Derek Jarman.

1389.84.text: Early in his career, Jarman worked as production designer

1393.48.text: on which 1971 film by the director Ken Russell,

1396.76.text: concerning the 17th-century witch trials at Loudon in France?

1405.68.text:
- Any ideas? 
- Do you know? 
- No, I don't.

1408.00.text:
- We don't know. 
- It's The Devils.

1409.68.text: Which Christian martyr of the third century

1412.16.text: was the title character of Jarman's 1976 film

1414.68.text: in which the dialogue was spoken entirely in Latin?

1425.48.text: And finally, in 1986, Jarman made a short film,

1428.44.text: conceptualising the music of which English rock group?

1432.04.text: Featuring their songs The Queen Is Dead, Panic,

1435.12.text: and There Is A Light That Never Goes Out.

1440.68.text: Listen carefully - for your answer I'll allow ten either way.

1443.28.text: What number results if you subtract the total number of

1446.68.text: Assembly Members in the Welsh National Assembly

1449.60.text: from the total number of MPs in the House of Commons?

1466.64.text: I'll except that! It's 590, in fact. Yes, well done.

1473.92.text: Your bonuses this time, Sheffield, are on chemical substances.

1478.28.text: Firstly, used on the cutting edges of saws and drills to give resistance

1481.80.text: to wear, what unusually hard substance has the chemical symbol WC?

1490.48.text: Found in steel, the hard, brittle substance known as cementite

1494.40.text: is a carbide of which metal?

1507.68.text: And finally, calcium carbide reacts with water to give which simple hydrocarbon?

1522.00.text: We're going to take another starter question now.

1524.84.text: From an Arabic word meaning soda ash or potash, what six-letter term

1530.08.text: denotes a strong base that turns litmus paper from red to blue?

1542.20.text: Right, Sheffield, these bonuses are on the

1544.72.text: Forbes List Of The World's 100 Most Powerful Women, published in 2015.

1548.88.text: Occupying sixth place on the Forbes list,

1551.16.text: which French lawyer and politician became the managing director

1555.24.text: of the International Monetary Fund in 2011?

1559.00.text:
- Christine...? 
- Yes. 
- Is it Christine Lagarde? Christine Lagarde.

1564.52.text: Janet Yellen is ranked in fourth place, having become in 2014

1568.92.text: the first female head of which financial institution?

1579.48.text:
- We're going to have to guess this. 
- So, we're guessing...?

1588.44.text: It's the US Federal Reserve. And finally:

1591.12.text: Name both of the political figures who occupy

1593.52.text: the top two positions on the Forbes list?

1598.24.text:
- Hillary Clinton's got to be one, hasn't she? 
- And Angela...?

1603.20.text:
- Angela Merkel and Hillary Clinton. 
- Correct.

1609.76.text: The Adoration Of The Magi, now in the Uffizi, depicts several members

1613.88.text: of which family, prominent in Florence for much of the Renaissance?

1623.84.text: You get bonuses on the works of Agatha Christie.

1626.36.text: In the 1933 novel, Murder On The Orient Express, the victim,

1629.88.text: Mr Ratchett, is murdered in his train compartment

1632.56.text: and is found with how many stab wounds?

1640.04.text: Christie's play The Mousetrap has been

1642.40.text: running in the West End for over 60 years,

1644.44.text: most recently at St Martin's Theatre.

1646.84.text: It opened in 1952 at which adjacent venue?

1653.32.text:
- Come on, let's have it, please? 
- We don't know. 
- Just have a guess.

1661.96.text: I'll tell you, it opened at the Ambassadors Theatre.

1666.28.text: Aberdeen, bad luck - you never really got into your stride there, did you?

1672.64.text: 185 is certainly enough to qualify for the semifinals.

1676.88.text: And we shall look forward to saying goodbye to you, quite presumably!

1682.88.text: I hope you can join us next time for the last of the first-round matches.

1686.00.text:
- But until then, it's goodbye from Aberdeen University. 
- Goodbye.

1689.00.text:
- It's goodbye from Sheffield University. 
- Goodbye.

1691.28.text: And it's goodbye from me. Goodbye.
